Teaching Assistant Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute January 2007  –  May 2007  (5 months) I supervised a batch of 20 undergraduate students in biochemistry laboratory. Research Associate Wockhardt R&D July 2004  –  July 2006  (2 years 1 month) During my stay at Wockhardt I worked with the Biotech R&D group on developing expression systems for production of different therapeutic proteins. My responsibilities included standardizing media at flask level experiments, optimizing media & substrate feeding strategies and evaluating different induction strategies for upto 20L fed-batch and semi-continuous fermentation, scaling up the fermentation processes from 20L to 1500L scale and standardizing protein folding process for various therapeutic proteins. I also had an opportunity working in a FDA approved production facility during the technology transfer from R&D to production. Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute PhD,  Chemical Engineering 2006  – 2011 My doctoral thesis revolves around stem-cell related research and drug discovery. First part of my research involves the design of novel 3-D matrices for encapsulation of stem cells and studying their influence on stem cell fate and delivery of exogenous factors to spinal cord injury site. The second part of my research deals with designing polyvalent inhibitors of HIV and siRNA-based approach to prevent influenza virus infection and transmission. Birla Institute of Technology and Science MS,  Biotechnology 2002  – 2004 While pursuing MS degree, I also had an opportunity to do graduate internship at Industrial Toxiology Research Center, India, a Council of Scientific and Industrial Research(CSIR) Laboratory. There I worked as a graduate research assistant on in vivo genotoxicity assessment of cypermethrin in mice using Comet assay.The study described the genotoxic effects of cypermethrin, a synthetic pyrethroid; a broad spectrum, non-cumulative insecticide; and, a fast-acting neurotoxin on multiple organs of mice using comet assay and micronucleus assay.The study had for the first time provided a comparative measurement of genotoxicity of cypermethrin on multiple organs of mice using comet assay. Summary Gazi Islam completed PhD in Biomedical Informatics from Arizona State University in 2013 where he worked on an NSF funded project which involved applying computer vision and machine learning algorithm to evaluate performance of surgical residents from laparoscopic surgery videos. Gazi graduated with a bachelor’s degree in Electrical Engineering from Islamic University of Technology, Bangladesh. After graduation, he served as a lecturer and taught core electrical engineering courses at the same institute for two years. Subsequently he attended Arizona State University where he received a Master’s degree in Electrical Engineering. He also worked as a Software Engineer Intern at Intel Corporation where he developed next generation perceptual computing technologies. Gazi has published more than 15 scientific articles in recognized journals and conferences including a book chapter. His expertise is in Computer Vision, HCI, Machine Learning, Image/Video Processing, Clinical and Imaging Informatics, Digital Logic, VLSI and Telecommunications. Currently Gazi is working as a development engineer at Intel Corporation in Hillsboro, Oregon. Experience PTD Engineer Intel Corporation July 2014  – Present (1 year 2 months) hillsboro, oregon Graduate Research Associate Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of North Texas August 2010  –  May 2014  (3 years 10 months) My area of interest is understanding laser material interactions with an emphasis on crystallization of amorphous precursors and synthesis of amorphous coatings. 
 
The study on crystallization behavior of amorphous materials involved understanding the underlying physics behind laser material interaction and its effects on phase transformation from amorphous to crystalline state. A microstructure-property-processing correlation is established in order to synthesize novel magnetic materials. The effects of laser material interaction are assessed by extensive characterization using analytical tools including DSC,XRD,SEM, TEM and Atom Probe Tomography. On the basis of microstructure-processing co-relationship, the laser processing parameters are optimized to enhance the magnetic property of the crystallized material. 
 
Synthesizing Fe-based bulk amorphous coatings on structural steels for extreme environments involves synthesizing bulk amorphous coatings by choosing appropriate laser parameters to obtain a sound coating with desired microstructure. Laser processing experiments are designed and performed keeping in view of various aspects like dilution ratio from the substrate, thermal histories and cooling rates, atmospheric effects like oxidation, contamination and also re-heating effects. Efficient ways of heat transfer are also designed depending on the requirement.The synthesized coatings are tested for corrosion and wear resistance. The tested samples are further analyzed using analytical tools like XRD,SEM, TEM and Atom Probe Tomography in order to understand the mechanisms operating during corrosion and wear.  
 
I also work on COMSOL modelling to evaluate the thermal histories experience during processing and validate the results using experimental observations (Open) 1 organization Materials Advantage UNT Chapter View (Open) 4 honors and awards Invited Member of Phi Kappa Phi View 4th position in Inter-university North Texas Student Symposium View Tolhouse Graduate School Travel Grant View Tolhouse Graduate School Travel Grant View (Open) 10 courses Advanced Physical Metalurgy Thermodynamics of Materials Bonding Structure and Crystallography Mechanical Behavior of Materials Electronic, Optical and Magnetic Properties of Materials Phase Transformations in Materials Compound Semiconductors Applied Fracture Mechanics SEM and FIB Transmission Electron Microscopy See more (Open) 1 recommendation Junyeon Hwang Senior Researcher at Korea Institute of Science and Technology Shravan is very sincere and self motivated not only for his work but also his life. Summary 1. Commitment: Strong commitment in collaboration breeds breakthrough velocity enabling for fully integrated MotherBoard/Pan delivery & STHI start-up project. This earns recognition from ATM Achievement Award and Divisional Recognition Award. 
2. Quality: Demonstrate highest standards of excellence in work quality such as delivered detail and qualitative DFM review feedbacks which help to achieve quality board layout in all the Haswell tester boards. 
3. Problem Solving: Lead task force to carry out few DOE and strain gauge measurement to collect the data and do the risk assessment on minor crack on NCTF balls issue. The data collection is used to make the final decision on the disposition. The team has managed to reduce the defect rate from 90% to 14.3%. 
4.Result orientation: Always practice result orientated on his job, he focus on output gain from his work. Willing to spend more time to check on DFM for each motherboard tapeout and provide the detailed DFM feedback to design team to ensure the design is meets the DFM requirement, this is important to make sure the product build can be executed flawlessly.
